Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Geospatial Modeling of Tropical Cyclones to Improve the Understanding of Rainfall Patterns

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Both the atmosphere and the earth's surface act to change the structure of a tropical cyclone during landfall. These structural changes affect the overall spatial patterns of rainfall produced by the storm, which then control the magnitude and timing of flooding that may occur. Although models of tropical cyclones have incorporated geophysical variables such as wind shear and terrain to improve the prediction of rainfall totals, they are still lacking in their ability to accurately depict the geographical distribution of the rainfall. This project addresses the critical need to improve the spatial modeling of tropical cyclone rain fields. Shape analysis techniques employed within a Geographic Information System (GIS) will quantify the extent and locations of rain-producing regions of tropical cyclones, including heavy rainfall regions as defined by radar reflectivity returns. These regions will then be linked to key geophysical variables that influence the storm's structure through comparisons of observed patterns against data from model-generated storms. The research supported through this CAREER award will develop a set of metrics to describe shapes that tropical cyclone rain fields frequently resemble to determine the processes responsible for creating those shapes, and it will derive statistical models to predict those shapes. By modeling rain field shapes within a GIS, these shapes can potentially be incorporated into pre-existing GIS-based hydrological models to improve the rainfall inputs into these models. Multivariate logistic regression analysis will also be employed to predict which areas will receive no rain versus some rain, and low rainfall rates versus high rainfall rates. This research will contribute to improving rainfall forecasting, both through the quantification of tropical cyclone rain fields and the improved ability to identify the location of flood-producing rainfall.

An integral component of this project is an effort to educate a new generation of researchers in advanced spatial analysis techniques. These efforts will contribute to cultivating innovative perspectives and fostering further improvement of rain forecasts for tropical cyclones that reach land. These outcomes will be achieved through an educational program that emphasizes GIS-based analysis of meteorological and climatological data. Both graduate and undergraduate students will receive enhanced training in GIS-based atmospheric data analysis and two newly designed courses will allow an undergraduate minor in meteorology to be developed. Students, both funded and non-funded, will undertake individual research projects related to the spatial analysis of weather events, interact with a series of topically relevant special guest lecturers from outside the university, and travel to professional meetings and workshops featuring GIS or weather-related research. Mentoring activities are expected to increase the number of minority students selecting science-based careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As we have witnessed during recent Hurricanes Matthew (2016), Harvey (2017), Maria (2017) and Florence (2018), flooding produced by tropical cyclones (TCs) poses a great hazard and more research is needed to understand where and when TC-related rainfall will occur. This project pursued two goals related to research on the rain fields of landfalling TCs and one related to education of undergraduate and graduate students. Specific Aim #1 was to develop and employ spatial metrics to quantify the rain-field patterns of TCs and included developing techniques to define the rain field?s edge, identifying regions where high rain rates occurred, and making comparisons between observed and modeled storms. Specific Aim #2 was to determine which atmospheric and surface-based variables combine to produce the spatial configurations of TC rain fields and develop statistical models to predict these distributions. The educational goal was to train students, especially women and minorities, to employ spatial analysis techniques to the analysis of meteorological and climatological data.

Students have played key roles in this research. We have analyzed Atlantic Basin TCs making landfall over the continental U.S., Puerto Rico, Central America and Mexico. We have identified the edges of rainfall produced by TCs and regions of higher rain rates in gauge-based rainfall observations, rain rates estimated from satellite observations, and reflectivity values detected by ground-based radars. We have also examined atmospheric conditions in three long-term reanalysis datasets and in forecasting model outputs from the Weather Research and Forecasting model and Global Forecast System final analysis. We are continuing this research as well as working to identify the location and timing of TC-related flood events. We developed eight spatial metrics and performed statistical analyses to compare one or more groups of observations, correlate conditions with the spatial metrics, identify spatial and temporal clustering of spatial metrics and environmental conditions, and predict the spatial configurations of rain rates. Nineteen manuscripts have been published in peer-reviewed journals with four more in progress. The PI has delivered 40 presentations at various meetings, conferences, and as an invited guest speaker in the local community and at other universities. There have been 63 presentations of results by students.

Intellectual Merit: We have developed a new technique to create a 3D mosaic of radar data and found that including a semi-Lagrangian trajectory could improve forecasts of rain distribution out to 6 hours over linear extrapolation methods. We performed the first known analysis of TC structure as resolved in the North American Regional Reanalysis dataset, concluding that after 2003, this dataset can be used to reliably study TCs over the Atlantic Ocean, Gulf of Mexico, and Caribbean Sea that are not near the domain boundary or complex terrain. TC rain fields expand as they move over the U.S. more often than they contract, increasing the number of regions that receive rainfall. In many cases, rainfall begins more than 24 hours prior to landfall, and may last for more than 24 hours. Also, rain field shapes tend to undergo statistically significant changes about 24 hours prior to landfall and precede changes in storm intensity. Regardless of location within the regions that we studied, our statistical analyses showed that the amount and spatial distribution of moisture played a key role in the configuration of TC rainbands and production of storm-total rainfall.

Broader Impacts: Thirty students have participated in this project, with over 50% being women or minorities, including military veterans. Four Ph.D. dissertations, two M.S. theses, and one undergraduate honor?s thesis have been produced, and three undergraduates participated through the University Scholars Program at the University of Florida (UF). At UF, two new courses, two courses developed for online delivery, and new certificates in Meteorology and Climatology and Applied Atmospheric Science have exposed more students, especially women and minorities, to concepts and terminology and provided training in analytical techniques in climatology, meteorology, and Geographic Information Systems than before this project. Fifty-two students have earned a certificate, 35 students are currently enrolled, and > 60% of all students are women and/or minorities. Research results have been widely disseminated through media interviews, local lectures in the community, conference presentations, and peer-reviewed journals. We have published course modules and computer codes on publically-available websites.
